Award.AwardTitle: Searches for Gravitational Wave Transients: Data Analysis and Detector Characterization for Advanced LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravitational waves are ripples in the curvature of space-time created by moving masses, which travel through the universe at the speed of light. Predicted by Einstein's Theory of General Relativity (GR) - the most commonly accepted model of gravity - gravitational waves have not been detected yet. The direct observations of gravitational waves would be one of the most fundamental results in the modern science and the ultimate test of GR. Also gravitational waves will be a radically new tool for exploring fundamental physics and astronomy. They will probe the physics driving the most violent astrophysical events in the universe in ways inaccessible to electromagnetic astronomy. The construction of the U.S. Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (aLIGO) is almost complete. The aLIGO detectors will conduct the first observations in the fall 2015. Within the next few years, aLIGO and its international partner detectors Virgo and Kagra expect to make the first detections of gravitational waves from merging compact binary objects, such as neutron stars and black holes. Gravitational waves produced by the collision of black holes, asymmetric core collapse supernovae, rapidly spinning neutron stars, and even by the Big Bang itself are targets for detection in the years to come.

This award supports high priority searches for gravitational-wave transients from a broad class of astrophysical sources. These searches are capable of detecting gravitational transients in a wide range of source parameters, including yet unknown sources. They target the most extreme astrophysical events, such as supernovae, gamma-ray-bursts, mergers of neutron stars and black holes, and hold a promise for discoveries of entirely new astrophysical phenomena. Also, they will extend the most promising advanced LIGO searches for compact binary sources into the binary parameter space not covered by the existing template algorithms. These searches have a potential to establish the existence of intermediate mass binary black holes, look inside the galactic nuclei by detecting binaries with the eccentric orbits, and test the theory of general relativity at high field regime with the intermediate mass ratio binary sources. Rapid source reconstruction and sky localization will enable joint observations, with the electromagnetic telescopes advancing the field of the multi-messenger astronomy. Sophisticated signal processing algorithms and source reconstruction methods will be implemented and applied to find the source polarization and waveforms. A novel wavelet regression method will be used for the analysis and characterization of aLIGO data, targeting identification, monitoring and cancellation of environmental noise coupled into the detector output. Studies of noise sources will be performed and novel noise cancellation techniques will be tested to enable the first confident detection of gravitational-wave transients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcome of the project is the first detection of gravitational waves from a merger of two black holes. On September 14, 2015 the signal (dubbed GW150914) was discovered in LIGO data by the Coherent Waveburst (CWB) algorithm three minutes after it was recorded by LIGO detectors.  Parameters of the event, including the chirp mass, sky location and signal waveforms were measured, showing unexpectedly high mass binary system. Sky location of the event was reported to the LIGO partner telescopes for the electro-magnetic follow-up of the event. This prompt CWB discovery triggered an extensive and critical study of the event in the first few hours after detection. The commissioning of LIGO detectors were stopped and additional data taking for validation of the event started. Work has been done on the mitigation of the false alarm rates and on the estimation of the event significance, which allowed LIGO to claim the first direct observation of a gravitational wave signal from an astrophysical source.  The results of the CWB analysis were published in the GW150914 discovery paper. The Coherent waveBurst contribution has been acknowledged in the official description of the 2017 Nobel prize in physics awarded to Rainer Weiss, Barry C. Barish and Kip S. Thorne. 

Following the GW150814 detection, the project participants played a key role in the CWB analysis of the O1 data and the publication of the LIGO results. The cWB all-sky searches for short and long duration burst signals targeting a wide class of generic bursts have been conducted.  A dedicated search for the intermediate mass black hole binaries (IMBHB) in the total mass range 100−600 Mo has been performed seting the most stringent rate limits approaching interesting astrophysical rate estimates. 

The cWB pipeline contributed into the detection and analysis of the other events detected by LIGO. The project participants executed a dedicated weakly-modeled cWB search for stellar mass binary black holes (BBH) during the O1 and O2 runs. The objective of this search was to complement the existing template (CBC) searches by detecting potential BBH signals not covered by the current template banks. Such search is robust to a variety of the BBH signal features including the higher order modes, high mass ratios, misaligned spins, eccentric orbits and possible deviations from the general relativity, that may not be captured by template searhes. Such search has the potential to discover new and possibly unexpected BBH populations. This dedicated cWB search has detected the LIGO events GW170104, GW170608, GW170814, GW170823 and the first BNS event GW170817 with high significance. Additionally, cWB detected a BBH signal (July 29th event), which was not detected by the template searches with high confidence. Studies of this event were performed including comparison of the signal waveforms reconstructed by the cWB and the CBC pipelines with the new statistical method developed at UF and INFN Padova. The chirp mass of the detected events, their sky location, waveforms and other parameters have been reconstructed - all in a good agreement with the template analysis. The results were published in the O1/O2 catalog paper.

The project participants also worked on prompt detection and reconstruction of GW signals and provided public alerts to the astronomical community. In addition to the O1 online all-sky search the UF group run a dedicated weakly-modeled search for stellar mass binary black hole signals.  The Coherent WaveBurst online analysis was reporting the location of potential sources triggering the followup of potential GW event with the partner telescopes.

Significant work has been done to understand and address major populations of transient spurious events (glitches) in the LIGO data. cWB pipeline has provided data to the LIGO DetChar group to study correlations between glitches. The UF postdoc and graduate student worked for 3 months as LIGO Fellow in Livingston to do studies of the scattered light noise in LIGO and studies of the up-conversion noise. 

As part of the preparation to the second advanced LIGO run a new version of CWB pipeline has been released before the start of O2. It was enhanced with a new clustering algorithm based on construction of time-frequency (wavelet) packets, which significantly improved waveform reconstruction and background rejection. Also work has been done to improve the computational performance of the CWB pipeline.

The research carried by the project promoted teaching, training and learning. The UF group graduate student working on development of strategies for joint observations with the gravitational wave detectors and telescopes successfully graduated in spring 2017 and accepted a postdoc position at Monash University, Melbourne, Australia. Also the broader impact of the UF research has been highlighted by Prof. Yves Meyer, the recipient of 2017 Abel Prize, who acknowledged the UF work on wavelets in his prize lecture ?Detection of gravitational waves and time-frequency wavelets? at the University of Oslo on May 24, 2017
